results.title: Thinking about drinking
results.brief_description: Presents the facts about alcoholic beverages with emphasis on their effects on the nervous system and behaviour. An alcoholic is a person who drinks so much that it interferes with their work and health, and alcoholism is a disease which constitutes a major health problem.

results.title: Think twice: they're confusing you
results.brief_description: Illustrates kinds of faulty or misleading information, such as oversimplification, distortions of fact, and logical fallacies. Designed to encourage critical thinking about the information which permeates public and personal communication. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Think twice: the persuasion game
results.brief_description: This film presents vignettes which dramatise ways in which the power of persuasion is used to influence the public. Appeals are made to one’s emotions. Fear, vanity, pride, justice and one’s desire to belong are utilised. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Think of the future
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and Central Office of Information for European Productivity Agency
results.brief_description: A cartoon contrasting improved modern conditions of work with the “good old days” when working and living conditions were in fact very much inferior. Only by increased production can the present high living standard be maintained and improved; to this end co-operation between workers and management is essential.

results.title: Think big
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Robin Hughes and Susan Doring
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Working series”.
One of a series of films about the place of work in people’s lives. To be really successful one needs determination and hard work. Many executives put work before the family causing conflicts, but a choice has to be made. Two executives, a man and a married woman discuss their jobs.

results.title: Think back: an introduction to safe and efficient patient transfer and object handling
results.creator_credit: Australia. Repatriation Dept., Geoff Crane and Phil Fury
results.brief_description:
This 1975 film, commissioned by the Australian Repatriation Department, provides instruction on the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back injury. The film contains three distinct sections: the first focusing on the principles for lifting heavy objects; the second showing different methods for lifting patients in the hospital; and the third showing methods for manoeuvring heavy loads such as shovelling material and pushing a trolley.

The first section includes animated sections showing the anatomy of the spine and the different types of back injury, including slipped disks, muscle and ligament strain. It then outlines the steps for lifting a heavy load, focusing on a truck driver loading various objects onto the tray of his vehicle.

The second section is directed at hospital staff, as an instructional video for lifting patients correctly. It shows methods of lifting patients up in bed, into a wheelchair and into a bath. Of particular note is the athletic wear (leotards and tracksuits) of the period worn by the nurses and patients in the demonstrations.

The third section shows methods of manual handling in everyday life with correct posture and stability, including shovelling material; pushing a trolley; and lifting a box into the back seat of a car.

A Repatriation Commission Film
Consultant: David Ferguson, Associate Professor in occupational health, the University of Sydney

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Thingumajigs = Trouvailles ou bizarreries

results.title: Things worth keeping
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television and Boris Holtzman
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Surveys worldwide problems of preserving cultural heritage, including unique buildings, historical sites and established neighbourhoods, as opposed to the construction of airports, super highways and industrial sites.
